title: 100-year-old Mets fan, born 43 yrs. before the team - New York Daily News
text:
Aaron Showalter/for New York Daily News 100-year-old Adeline Russo has been a die-hard Mets fan since the start of the team. 
Meet the Mets Whisperer — a Westchester granny who turned 100 the day before the Amazins’ punched their ticket to Saturday’s showdown with the Chicago Cubs. 
Whenever the Mets play, Adeline Russo plants herself in her light blue armchair, turns on her 22-inch Samsung television, and starts her non-stop baseball patter. 
“I’m right there, I’m right in there with them,” Russo, dressed in a blue Mets jersey and wearing an orange Mets cap, said Friday. “I’m talking to them all the time. Sometimes they listen to me, sometimes they don’t.” 
On Thursday, for example, Russo said she gave struggling Mets pitcher Jacob deGrom a pep talk. 
“He was kind of losing because they were hitting him,” she said. “I said, ‘C’mon deGrom, you can get out of that.’ Sure enough, he got out of it. He listened to me.” 
Russo’s 77-year-old son, Gerry, said it’s a wonder deGrom didn’t hear his mom. 
FAMOUS SAD METS FANS CELEBRATE METS NLDS VICTORY TOGETHER AT DODGERS STADIUM 
“I can hear her all the way in the other wing of the house,” said the younger Russo, who lives in a sprawling Bedford, N.Y. mansion. “Usually she’s saying things like, ‘Get him out of there! He can’t hit! Or, he’s a terrible batter.’” 
Born in Pennsylvania and raised in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Russo has been a Mets fans all 53 years of the team’s existence. 
For the first half of her life, Russo rooted for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Then they broke her heart. 
“When they went to California, I washed my hands of them,” she said. “They gave up on Brooklyn.” 
So when the Mets arrived, she bought season tickets. “I have no use for the Yankees,” she said. 
Russo said she stuck by the Mets through thick and thin and went to as many games as she could, including every home game of the 1986 World Series which the Mets won. 
“All the years I’ve been ribbed about them, but I’m still a Mets fan,” she said. “I take them good and take them bad but they are still my favorite.” 
Russo will be back in her favorite chair on Saturday — and she’ll be talking. 
“I pray to God that the Mets win,” she said. “The Cubs are a good team too.” 
Russo isn’t just a longtime Mets fan, she’s a lifelong reader of The Daily News, which appeared on newsstands in 1919 — when she was four. 
“I get the News every day,” said Russo, who started reading the News in 1936.
